questions.text:
Arrange in sequence the structures involved in the direct pathway:

1. Striatum
2. Globus pallidus
3. Substantia nigra
4. Thalamus
5. Cortex
questions.solution:
The sequence of structures involved in the direct pathway is cortex > striatum > globus pallidus > substantia nigra > thalamus.

There are five parallel circuits that connect the frontal cortex to the striatum, pallidum, substantia nigra, and thalamus. These circuits have both direct and indirect pathways. The direct pathway stimulates the cortex to produce movement, whereas the indirect pathway inhibit it. 

The cerebral cortex projects into the striatum. The striatum is seen projected into the pallidum and substantia nigra pars reticularis. Fibres originate from different striatal cells according to their endings in the external and internal pallidum. In the direct pathway, striatal neurones project directly to the internal pallidum.  Whereas some other fibres that arise from the neurons project to the external pallidum. This is called the indirect pathway.  

The sequence of structures involved in the indirect pathway is cortex > striatum > globus pallidus externa > subthalamic nucleus > globus pallidus interna and substantia nigra >Thalamus

The striatal activity in the direct pathway is mediated by D1 dopamine receptors and in the indirect pathway by D2 dopamine receptors. 

Putamen lies lateral and the internal capsule lies medial to the pallidum. It receives fibres from the striatum and subthalamic nuclei. It acts as the main output of the basal ganglia to the thalamus and superior colliculus. The substantia nigra is seen in each cerebral peduncle of the midbrain located deep to the crus cerebri. The levels of dopamine in the substantia nigra and striata are seen reduced in parkinsonism disease.

In parkinsonism disease, due to the death of neurons in substantia nigra activity of the direct pathway is reduced and the indirect pathway is increased. This results in bradykinesia in parkinsonism disease. Whereas in Huntington's disease, the activity of the indirect pathway is affected resulting in choreic involuntary movements.

questions.text: What is the volume of the prostate in normal adult males?
questions.solution:
The volume of the prostate in normal adult males is 20cc.

Prostate is an accessory glandular tissue embedded in the fibromuscular stroma. It usually weighs 8 grams in the young adults and its weight ranges from 40-150 grams in men aged >50 years. 

The prostate gland is situated in the lesser pelvis and surrounds the prostatic urethra which extends from bladder base to the membranous urethra. Pubic symphysis and pubic arch lie anteriorly to the prostate whereas rectourethralis and rectal ampulla lie posteriorly to it. 

The prostate has three distinct zones as follows:

Zone Structures enclosed Clinical significance
Transitional zone Urethra  Most common site for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)
Central zone Ejaculatory ducts Atrophies secondary to BPH
Peripheral zone

Central and transitional zones Pre-prostatic urethra

 Most common site for prostatic carcinoma

 

The prostate is composed of 5 lobes. They are anterior, posterior, two lateral and one medial or middle lobe. 

The median lobe of the prostate forms the uvula vesicae. It is an elevation found in the lower part of the bladder trigone. It is the most common site of adenoma. 

 

Microstructure of the prostate gland: 

The glandular tissue of the prostate gland is composed of many follicles with frequent internal papillae. The follicular epithelium is either a single-layered or pseudostratified columnar epithelum. These follicles open into canals, which join to form the main ducts. Small eosinophilic colloid amyloid bodies called corpora amylacea are frequently seen within a follicle. 

The prostatic ducts open into the prostatic sinus in the prostatic urethra. The ducts of the prostate follicles are lined by bilayered epithelium (basal cuboidal and apical columnar). 

The secretions of the prostate are acidic and contain acid phosphatase, amylase, prostate-specific antigen (PSA), fibrin, and zinc.

The blood supply to the prostate is by the inferior vesical, internal pudendal and middle rectal arteries. It recieves nerve supply from the inferior hypogastric plexus.

questions.text: Which ligament connects medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal?
questions.solution:
The Lisfranc ligament connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal.

Lisfranc ligament is a cuneometatarsal interosseous ligament. It is the strongest ligament among the three cuneometatarsal interosseous ligaments. It passes from the lateral surface of the medial cuneiform to the adjacent angle of the second metatarsal bone. 

Deformity of this ligament can lead to instability and deformity of the tarsometatarsal joint.

Other options:
Option A: Chopart's ligament is related to both calcaneocuboid and calcaneonavicular joints. It is a strong Y-shaped band, having a proximal stem and 2 distal limbs.

  • The proximal limb is attached by a stem to the anterior part of the upper calcaneal surface.
  • The distal limb divides into calcaneocuboid and calcaneonavicular parts.

Option B: Spring ligament also known as the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament connects the sustentaculum tali to the navicular. It ties the calcaneus to the navicular and maintains the medial longitudinal arch of the foot. It is made up of the superomedial calcaneonavicular portion and the inferior calcaneonavicular portion.

Option D: Deltoid ligament also called the medial collateral ligament is attached to the apex, anterior and posterior borders of the medial malleolus. It has 2 layers, superficial and deep:

  • The superficial layer consists of tibionavicular fibres anteriorly, tibiocalcaneal fibres in the middle, and superficial posterior tibiotalar fibres posteriorly.
  • Deep layer consists of anterior tibiotalar fibres, tibiocalcaneal in the middle and deep posterior tibiotalar posteriorly.

questions.text: Fibres of the given structure originate from ?
questions.solution:
The given structure is the fornix and its fibres arise from the hippocampus. 

The fornix is a part of the connecting pathways of the limbic system. It arises from the hippocampus which wraps around the thalamus and ends in the mammillary body. It connects the hippocampus with distal brain sites. 

The fornix has two types of fibres:

  • Association fibres: They connect the various cortical regions within the same hemisphere 
  • Commissural fibres: They connect the corresponding regions of two hemispheres. It is seen in the hippocampal commissure of the fornix. 

The blood supply of fornix is by the anterior communicating artery which arises from the anterior cerebral artery. 

The limbic system is a group of structures seen between the cerebral cortex and the hypothalamus. It is involved in emotional and motivation activity, learning, and memory. 

Other options:

Option A: Amygdala is a part of the limbic system that consists of lateral, central and basal nuclei. It can Influence the body's response to enviromnental changes. In a fearful situation it can change the heart rate, blood pressure, respiratory rate etc. 

Option C: Caudate nucleus is a C-shaped mass of grey matter. It is divided into a head, body, and tail. Degeneration of the caudate nucleus is seen in Huntington's disease. 

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: Which structure is supplied by the nerve causing this elevation?
questions.solution:
Risorius is supplied by the facial nerve which causes the elevation marked. The image shows the floor of the fourth ventricle and the facial colliculus is marked. 

The fourth ventricle is located between the brainstem and the cerebellum. The rhomboid fossa is a diamond-shaped depression seen on the floor of the fourth ventricle. The superior and the inferior part of the floor is triangular in shape. It is divided by a longitudinal median sulcus into two halves. Each half is again divided into the medial and lateral regions.

The facial colliculus is present in the superior part, which presents as a small elevation produced by the root of the facial nerve winding around the nucleus of the abducens nerve.  Columns are formed by groups of facial neurones, which innervate individual muscles and give branches of the facial nerve. Dorsal neurones innervate muscles in the scalp and upper face and ventral neurons supply the lower facial musculature. 

Risorius falls under the buccolabial muscle group and act as the elevator, retractor and evertor of the upper lip. Some of its peripheral attachments are the zygomatic arch, parotid fascia and fascia over the mastoid process. It is involved in actions like grinning and laughing and is innervated by the buccal branches of the facial nerve.

Other options:

Option A: Lateral rectus is an extraocular muscle that arises from the lateral part of the common tendinous ring. It is innervated by the abducens nerve. 

Option B: Superior oblique is an extraocular muscle that arises from the body of the sphenoid. It is innervated by the trochlear nerve. 

Option D: Levator palpebrae superiors is an extraocular muscle that arises from the lesser wing of sphenoid. It is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. 

Related Pearl: Extraocular Muscles and Their Actions

questions.text:
Arrange lung hilar structures from anterior to posterior:

1. Primary bronchus
2. Bronchial artery
3. Pulmonary vein
4. Pulmonary artery
questions.solution:
Lung hilar structures are arranged from the anterior to posterior in the order:

  • Pulmonary vein
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Primary bronchus
  • Bronchial artery

 The medial surface of the lung is connected to the heart and trachea by a group of structures that enter or leave the hilum. It is called the pulmonary root. It is anteriorly related to the phrenic nerve, pericardiacophrenic vessels , and anterior pulmonary plexus. The vagus nerve and posterior pulmonary plexus form the posterior relation and the pulmonary ligament the inferior relation. 

The superior vena cava and right atrium are seen in front of the right root and terminal part of the azygos vein superiorly. The hilar structures are arranged from the superior to inferior as:

  • Superior lobar bronchus
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein 

The aortic arch is seen superiorly and descending thoracic aorta posteriorly of the left root. The hilar structures are vertically arranged as:

  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

Related Pearl: Structures related to the mediastinal surface and hilum of the lungs

Right lung:

  • Anterior to the hilum - superior vena cava and right brachiocephalic vein.
  • Posterior to this groove-  azygous vein.
  • Behind the hilum and pulmonary ligament- oesophagus.
  • The cardiac impression - right auricle, right atrium and right ventricle
  • Posteroinferiorly - inferior vena cava

Left lung:

  • The cardiac impression - left ventricle and auricle and right ventricle
  • Large groove that arches over the hilum and descends behind -  Arch of aorta and descending aorta.
  • Arrow groove that ascends to the apex- left subclavian artery
  • Superior to the aortic groove-  thoracic duct and esophagus.
  • Anterior to subclavian groove - left brachiocephalic vein.

questions.text: Which is not a branch of facial artery in the face?
questions.solution:
Mental is not a branch of the facial artery but the branch of the maxillary artery in the face.

The first part of the maxillary artery gives rise to the mental artery as a terminal branch of the inferior alveolar artery.

The facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery which arises in the carotid triangle, above the origin of the lingual artery. It runs upwards in the neck and curves around the anteroinferior border of the masseter to enter the face. 

Branches of facial artery in the neck Branches of facial artery in the face
Ascending palatine artery Premasseteric artery
Tonsillar branch Superior and inferior labial arteries
Submental artery Lateral nasal artery
Branches to submandibular gland Angular artery

The premasseteric artery passes along the anterior border of the masseter and the surrounding tissues are supplied by it. The inferior labial artery mainly supplies the inferior labial glands. It then anastomoses with its controlateral fellow and with the mental branch of the inferior alveolar artery. The superior labial artery supplies the upper lip whereas the lateral nasal artery supplies the dorsum and alae of the nose. Both these arteries anastomose with its controlateral fellow. 

The image shows the branches of facial artery:

questions.text: Which of the following structures passing via jugular foramen has a separate canal?
questions.solution:
The glossopharyngeal nerve passing through the jugular foramen has a separate canal.

 The jugular foramen is formed by the occipital bone and the petrous part of the temporal bone. The spinal accessory nerve and vagus nerve also pass through this foramen.

The glossopharyngeal nerve leaves the skull through the anteromedial part of the jugular foramen in a separate dural sheath.

The branches of the nerve are tympanic, carotid, pharyngeal, muscular, tonsillar and lingual branches.

Infection, malignancy and postoperative inflammation of the tonsil and tonsillar fossa will cause referred pain in the ear. This is conducted through the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and vagus nerve form the pharyngeal plexus of nerves. These plexes mainly supply the pharynx. It also has contributions from the superior cervical ganglion.

Nerve supply by the pharyngeal branch of the vagus nerve are:

  • All the muscles of the soft palate(except tensor veli palatini - supplied by mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve)
  • All the muscles of the pharynx(except stylopharyngeus - supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve)

 Motor fibres to the stylopharyngeus and parasympathetic secretomotor fibres to the parotid gland are also supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Sensory supply includes uvula, posterior one-third of the tongue, tympanic cavity etc.

The glossopharyngeal nerve is rarely damaged alone. Lesions will result in loss of sensation of the posterior third of the tongue, reduced gag reflex, loss of sensation over the ipsilateral soft palate etc. 

The main functions of IX and X can be tested together by assessing swallowing, phonation/articulation and sensation from the pharynx/larynx. 

Glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve examinations include:

  • Observing the position and symmetry of the palate and uvula at rest and with phonation (“aah”).
  • By assessing the strength of the cough

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image?
questions.solution:
The median nerve supplies the 1st lumbrical which is marked. 

There are four lumbrical muscles. They originate from the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus. It passes to the radial side of the corresponding fingers and is inserted into the dorsal digital expansion of the extensor digitorum.

The action of lumbricals is flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joint and extension of interphalangeal joints. 

Lumbricals can be tested only along with interosseous muscle. The examiner will hold the metacarpophalangeal joint of the index finger in hyperextension. Then the patient is asked to extend the proximal interphalangeal joint against resistance. The test is repeated on other fingers as well.

The median nerve innervates the first and second lumbricals. The deep terminal branch of the ulnar nerve innervates the third and the fourth. 

The median nerve is formed by the union of the lateral root (C6, 7) from the lateral cord, and the medial root (C8, T1) from the medial cord.

On the hand, it is seen proximal to the flexor retinaculum and lateral to the tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis. It also lies between the tendons of flexor carpi radialis and palmaris longus.

Its cutaneous supply in hand is as follows: 

  • Lateral 2/3rd of the palm by superficial cutaneous branch
  • Lateral 3½ fingers (palmar aspect and dorsal aspect of nailbeds) by palmar digital nerves

The muscles supplied by the median nerve in the hand are flexor pollicis brevis, abductor pollicis brevis, and opponens pollicis

The median nerve sometimes gets compressed under the fibro-osseous tunnel beneath the flexor retinaculum leading to carpal tunnel syndrome. 

Pen test is used to test the median nerve in the hand. It tests the abductor pollicis brevis muscle.  The hand must remain flat with the palm facing upwards. A pen is held above the palm and the patient is asked to touch the pen with his thumb.

questions.text: A child lacks thymus and inferior parathyroid glands. Defective development of which of the following structures is likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome. Defective development of the third pharyngeal pouch marked as 3 causes this condition.

A child with DiGeorge syndrome lacks thymus and inferior parathyroid glands due to defective development of the 3rd pharyngeal pouch. The child can also lack superior parathyroid glands, due to defective development of the 4th pharyngeal pouch. It is caused by chromosome 22q deletion and is characterized by the following (Mnemonic: CATCH-22)

  • Cleft palate
  • Abnormal facies
  • Thymic aplasia leading to T-cell deficiency and recurrent infections
  • Cardiac defects
  • Hypocalcemia, secondary to parathyroid aplasia. 

Derivatives of the Pharyngeal Pouches

1st Pouch

  • Tympanic cavity (middle ear cavity)
  • Auditory tube (eustachian tube) 

2nd Pouch

  • Palatine tonsils
  • Tonsillar fossa

3rd Pouch

  • Inferior parathyroid glands 
  • Thymus

4th Pouch

  • Superior parathyroid glands 
  • Ultimobranchial body - gives rise to parafollicular (C) cells of the thyroid gland

 

The medulla of the thymus has Hassall’s corpuscles. They are small rounded structures formed from whorls of medullary epithelial cells with a central partially keratinized core appearing as an eosinophilic-staining mass. 

Histological image of Hassall’s corpuscles is given below:

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

questions.text: Identify which of the following structure is a merocrine gland:
questions.solution:
Sweat gland marked 2 is a merocrine gland.

Eccrine and apocrine are the two types of sweat glands. Secretions of the sweat glands are by exocytosis hence they are also known as merocrine sweat glands. 

A histopathological image of the sweat gland is shown below:

The other structures marked are:
1- Hair follicle
3- Sebaceous gland
4- Hair shaft

Glands are divided into holocrine, apocrine, and merocrine on the basis of the manner in which their secretions are poured out of the cells.

In holocrine secretions, the secretory cells themselves are disintegrated as part of their terminal differentiation. Afterwhich, the terminally differentiated cells filled with lipid products are released. The sebaceous gland and hair follicles are examples. 

A histopathological image of the sebaceous gland is shown below:

Merocrine uses exocytosis for secretions. Most of the exocrine glands are merocrine.

In apocrine, product-filled areas of cells are released, the mammary gland is an example.

Histopathological image of mammary gland is shown below: 

Related Pearl: Comparison between Types of Sweat Glands

Feature

Apocrine sweat gland

Eccrine sweat gland

Activity

questions.text: What is the blood supply of the structure marked in the image below?

choices.text: Anterior cerebral artery and middle cerebral artery
Anterior cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery
Anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery
Middle cerebral artery and posterior cerebral artery

questions.solution:
Blood is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery and anterior communicating artery as the marked structure is the anterior part of the corpus callosum.

Corpus callosum is the largest fibre pathway of the brain. The parts of the corpus callosum are the rostrum, genu, trunk or body, and splenium. 

 The image below shows the parts of the corpus callosum: 

Anterior cerebral artery is a branch of the internal carotid artery. The frontal branch of the anterior cerebral artery supplies the corpus callosum and the central branch which supplies the rostrum. 

Central or perforating arteries arises from the circle of willis. They are again divided into the anteromedial, anterolateral, posteromedial and posterolateral groups. The anterior cerebral and anterior communicating artery give rise to anteromedial group which supplies the rostrum of the corpus callosum. 


The image below shows the mid sagittal section of the brain:

Related Pearl: Corpus Callosum

Parts of the corpus callosum:

  • Rostrum: connects frontal lobes (eg: orbitofrontal cortex)
  • Genu: connects frontal lobes. It is the anterior-most part.
  • Trunk or Body: connects temporal lobes.
  • Splenium: connects the two occipital lobes. It is the thickest part.

Note: Isthmus is a part which separates the body from splenium, some books mention it as a part.

  • The fibers of the genu curve forward into frontal lobes and form forceps minor.
  • The fibers of the trunk extend laterally as radiation of corpus callosum.
  • The fibers from the trunk and the splenium which form the lateral wall of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle constitute the tapetum.
  • The fibers from the splenium arching backwards into the occipital lobe form forceps major.

Related Pearl: Arteries supplying specific parts of the brain

  • Lateral striate artery - a branch of MCA
  • Medial striate artery - a branch of ACA
  • Anterior and posterior  choroidal arteries
  • Thalamogeniculate branch of PCA

Related Pearl: Blood supply of Brain

The brain is supplied by Internal Carotid arteries and Vertebrobasilar arteries. 

Areas supplied by various arteries
Anterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves around the corpus callosum within the sagittal fissure

Supply - Dorsomedial frontal and parietal lobes

Effects of occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA): 

- Contralateral Paralysis (or weakness) of muscles of the leg and foot - Upper part of motor area affected.

- Contralateral Loss (or dulling) of sensations from the leg and foot - Upper part of the sensory area affected.
Middle Cerebral Artery

Course - Runs within Sylvian fissure

Supply - Lateral convexity of the cerebral cortex

Effects of occlusion of middle cerebral artery (MCA):

- Contralateral Hemiplegia -  loss of sensations. The face and arms are most affected, foot and leg are spared.  

- Aphasia - Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas affected, especially if the thrombosis is in the left hemisphere in a right-handed person.  

- Contralateral Homonymous hemianopia - due to the involvement of optic radiation.  
Posterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves behind the midbrain

Supply - Occipital lobe and inferior and medial temporal lobe

Effects of occlusion of posterior cerebral artery (PCA):

- Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing - Affected Cortical blood supply > Damage to association cortex of visual area causes visual hallucinations (distortion of colour vision).

Note: Macular sparing is due to collateral circulation from MCA to that cortical region.

questions.text: Superior gluteal nerve supplies all of the following structures except:
questions.solution:
All of the structures except pyriformis are supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. Pyriformis is supplied by the nerve to the piriformis. 

The dorsal branches of the L4, L5, and S1 rami give rise to the superior gluteal nerve. It is accompanied by superior gluteal vessels. This nerve leaves the pelvis via the greater sciatic foramen above piriformis and divides into superior and inferior branches. It supplies gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae.

The dorsal branches of the S1 and S2 rami give rise to the nerve to the piriformis. 

Gluteus medius and gluteus minimus act as the abductors of the hip joint. Stabilizing the pelvis on the femur during walking is done by these muscles. It is demonstrated by asking the subject to stand on one limb. If the ipsilateral abductors are normal, the pelvis remains in a horizontal position. If the ipsilateral abductors are weak, then the pelvis tilts towards the opposite (unsupported) side. This is called positive Trendelenburg’s sign.

Related Pearl: Gluteal Muscles

 
Gluteus Medius
Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and posterior gluteal lines.
Insertion -Oblique ridge on the lateral surface of the greater trochanter.
Gluteus Minimus
Origin- Outer surface of ilium between anterior and inferior gluteal lines
Insertion -Ridge on the anterior surface of greater trochanter
Gluteus Maximus

Origin - Posterior aspect of dorsal ilium posterior to posterior gluteal line, posterior superior iliac crest, posterior inferior aspect of sacrum and coccyx, and sacrotuberous ligament

Insertion - Primarily in fascia lata at the iliotibial band; also into the gluteal tuberosity on posterior femoral surface

questions.text:
Arrange the structures of the cubital fossa in sequence from medial to lateral.

1. Median nerve
2. Radial nerve
3. Tendon of biceps brachii
4. Brachial artery
questions.solution:
The structures are arranged in the cubital fossa from medial to lateral as follows:

  • Median nerve
  • Brachial artery
  • Tendon of biceps brachii
  • Radial nerve

The cubital fossa is a triangular depression in the anterior aspect of the upper forearm. It is related to the epicondylar line proximally, lateral border of pronator teres medially, and by the medial surface of brachioradialis laterally. 

Its roof is formed by the deep fascia of the forearm. The floor of the fossa is formed by the brachialis and supinator. Veins like basilic, median cubital, and cephalic veins are arranged in the superficial fascia from medial to lateral side.

questions.text:
Arrange the cells according to their positions from the basal layer towards the lumen in the seminiferous tubules.

1. Spermatogonia
2. Primary spermatocyte
3. Spermatid
4. Spermatozoa
5. Myoepithelial cell
questions.solution:
From the basal layer towards the lumen in the seminiferous tubules, the cells are arranged in the order of:

  • Myoepithelial cells
  • Spermatogonia
  • Primary spermatocyte
  • Spermatid
  • Spermatozoa

Spermatogenesis is the process in which spermatogonia are transformed into spermatozoa. It begins at puberty. During puberty, the sex cords acquire lumen to become seminiferous tubules. The primordial germ cells give rise to spermatogonial stem cells. The transformation of spermatogonial stem cells to spermatozoa is given in the flowchart below.

The process by which spermatids are transformed into spermatozoa is called spermiogenesis.

questions.text: Which skull foramen is formed by 3 bones?
questions.solution:
Foramen lacerum is formed by three bones.

The three bones involved in the formation of foramen lacerum are: 

  • Petrous part of the temporal bone
  • Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • Basilar part of the occipital bone 

The internal carotid artery enters the skull through this foramen. It ascends through the carotid canal and from the upper end of the foramen lacerum. 

It is accompanied by venous and sympathetic nerve plexuses. It is also transversed by the meningeal branches of the ascending pharyngeal artery and emissary veins from the cavernous sinus.

On the anterior margin of the foramen lacerum pterygoid canal can be seen which leads to the pterygopalatine fossa. The nerve of the pterygoid canal and accompanying vessels are transmitted by them. 

The image below shows the base of the skull and foraminas:

Other options:

Option B: Foramen magnum is formed by the occipital bone. 

Option C: Foramen rotundum is a hole seen in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. 

 

Option D: Foramen jugulare is formed by the petrous part of the temporal bone and occipital bone. 

The image below shows superior and inferior views of the skull base:

questions.text: Which marked structure causes lateral rotation, flexion, and abduction at the hip joint, along with flexion at the knee joint?
questions.solution:
Sartorius is involved in lateral rotation, flexion, and abduction at the hip joint, and flexion at the knee. The structure marked '2' is sartorius.

The sartorius muscle is known as the tailor muscle and is also the longest muscle in the body. The word "sartorius" is derived from the Latin word sartor, which translates to tailor, due to the way the individual will position one's leg while working.

Origin: Anterior superior iliac spine and the upper half of the notch below it.

Insertion: Into the superior aspect of the medial surface of the tibial shaft near the tibial tuberosity (joins aponeurosis of gracilis and semitendinosus to form pes anserinus).

Action: Flexion, abduction, and lateral rotation of the thigh; and flexion of the leg.

Innervation: By femoral nerve (L2 and L3)

 

Other options:

Option A: Rectus femoris is involved in flexion at the hip and extension at the knee.

Option C: Gracilis is involved in adduction at the hip and flexion and medial rotation at the knee.

Option D: Adductor longus is involved in adduction, flexion, and medial rotation at the hip.

questions.text:
Which among the following statements is true regarding the course of the mandibular nerve?

1. Auriculotemporal nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the temporomandibular joint.
2. Buccal branch is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the mandibular ramus.
3. Lingual nerve is a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arcs around the submandibular duct.
4. Ophthalmic nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arises in the middle cranial fossa.
questions.solution:
The true statements are 2 and 3.

The lingual nerve is a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arcs around the submandibular duct. 

The buccal branch is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the mandibular ramus.

The other statements:

1. The auriculotemporal nerve emerges from behind the temporomandibular joint and is a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve. 

4. The ophthalmic nerve arises in the middle cranial fossa and is a division of the trigeminal nerve, along with the maxillary and mandibular nerves.

questions.text: The rupture of penile urethra does not cause extravasation of blood into which of the following spaces?
questions.solution:
Rupture of the penile urethra causes extravasation of blood into the superficial perineal pouch, scrotum, penis, and then up to the lower anterior abdominal wall.

The superficial perineal pouch is a compartment of the perineum enclosed by the membranous layer of the perineal fascia that surrounds the scrotum or labia and penis or clitoris.

Anteriorly, the membranous layer of perineal fascia is continuous over the pubic symphysis and pubic bones. It is later continuous with the membranous layer of the anterior abdominal wall.  Thus, the fluid that accumulates in the perineal pouch extends to the lower anterior abdomen.

In the lower lateral abdominal wall, the abdominal fascia is attached to the deep fascia of the thigh, inferior to the inguinal ligament. Thus, on trauma at the penile urethra, urine does not extravasate into the anterior thigh.

The superficial perineal pouch is closed posteriorly by attaching the membranous layer of superficial fascia to the posterior margin of the urogenital diaphragm. Thus, commonly there is no extravasation into the deep perineal pouch and the ischiorectal fossa.

Also, the membranous layer of superficial fascia attaches to the ischiopubic rami and forms the lateral borders of the urogenital triangle. Thus, the urine does not extravasate to the thigh.

But, the ischiorectal fossa would be a better answer because of the following reasons:

  1. Bulbourethral glands that lie in the deep perineal space open their ducts into the spongy urethra, which is related to the superficial perineal space. Also, the muscles surrounding these glands were recently found to be a continuation of the deep transverse perinei and tail of the external urethral sphincter, both of which are components of the deep perineal space. Injury to the penile urethra can damage bulbourethral glands' ducts, which can lead to damage to the above-mentioned structures and may cause extravasation of urine into the deep perineal space. 
  2. Previously, the perineal membrane was thought to be a triangular membrane. However, recent studies show that it is contiguous anteriorly with the structures that support the urethra. Posteriorly, it is related to the support of the perineal body and lateral vaginal wall. So damage to the urethra might damage the anterior part of the perineal membrane which can make way for extravasation of blood into the deep perineal space. 
  3. Deep perineal pouch: It was believed initially that the urogenital diaphragm was formed by 3 layers: An inferior fascia (also called the perineal membrane), deep perineal space, and a superior fascia. The superior fascia formed the inferior border of the ischioanal fossa. The Colles fascia also separates the perineal membrane from the ischioanal fossa. So, extravasation of blood into the deep perineal space is possible but extravasation into the ischioanal fossa due to penile urethral injury is highly unlikely. Recent studies have shown that this might be a slightly more complex structure.

questions.text: Which nerve is blocked when local anesthesia is given below the inguinal ligament during femoral vein catheterization?
questions.solution:
Genitofemoral nerve is blocked when the local anesthetic is given below the inguinal ligament during femoral vein catheterization. 

The genitofemoral nerve originates from the L1 and L2 ventral rami. It divides into the genital and femoral branches after crossing behind the ureter.

The genital branch enters the inguinal canal through the deep ring and accompanies the spermatic cord or round ligament. It exits the superficial inguinal ring and supplies the cremaster muscle and skin of the external genitalia.

The femoral branch descends lateral to the external iliac artery to pass behind the inguinal ligament and enter the femoral sheath lateral to the femoral artery. It pierces the anterior wall of the femoral sheath and fascia lata and supplies them.

The genitofemoral nerve gives sensory supply to the anteromedial thigh via the femoral branch. The genital branch supplies skin of the scrotum in males and mons pubis and labium majus in females. The genitofemoral nerve also innervates the cremaster muscle via the genital branch and is responsible for the cremasteric reflex.

The image given below shows nerves related to the inguinal region:

Other options:

Option A: Femoral nerve arises from the posterior division of ventral rami of L2-L4 spinal segments on the posterior abdominal wall. It enters the femoral triangle by passing under the inguinal ligament. In the femoral triangle, it lies lateral to the femoral artery and outside the femoral sheath. Later, it is divided into anterior and posterior branches by the lateral circumflex femoral artery.

Option C: Lateral cutaneous nerve (a.k.a lateral femoral cutaneous nerve) of the thigh is most commonly injured at the site where it leaves the pelvis. An injury to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh leads to pain and paresthesia over the anterolateral region of the thigh, a condition called meralgia paresthetica.

Option D: Ilioinguinal nerve is most commonly injured within the inguinal canal in open hernia repair due to traction or thermal injury. Injury causes loss of sensation in the root of the penis and adjacent part of the scrotum. 

 

Related Pearl: Femoral Triangle

The femoral triangle is a depressed, intermuscular space present in the anteromedial aspect of the proximal thigh.

Boundaries of Femoral triangle are:

Medially- Medial border of Adductor longus

Laterally- Medial border of Sartorius

Base- Inguinal ligament

Floor (lateral to medial)- Iliacus, Psoas major, Pectineus, Adductor longus

Roof- Skin, Superficial fascia, Fascia lata, superficial branches of femoral vessels–superficial epigastric, superficial external pudendal, superficial circumflex iliac vessels and GSV. 

Note: Femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve which forms a content of the triangle also forms its roof as it pierces the fascia to supply the skin over the triangle. 

Contents:

  • Femoral sheath containing lymph node of Cloquet, femoral vein, femoral artery, femoral branch of genitofemoral nerve.
  • Femoral nerve and its branches
  • Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.text: Identify the nerve passing around the marked structure.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given image is the neck of fibula. The nerve passing around the neck of fibula is the common peroneal nerve (common fibular nerve).

The common peroneal nerve is derived from the dorsal branches of the ventral rami of L4, L5, S1, and S2. The sciatic nerve divides into the tibial nerve and the common fibular nerve.

The common fibular nerve runs obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa to the fibular head. It lies between the biceps femoris and the lateral head of the gastrocnemius. It then curves laterally around the neck of the fibula and gets divided into superficial and deep fibular nerves.

Superficial fibular nerve:

Motor innervation: 

  • Peroneus longus
  • Peroneus brevis

Sensory innervation: 

  • Lateral aspect of the lower leg
  • Dorsum of the toes except for the lateral side of the 5th toe and the first interdigital webspace

Deep fibular nerve:

Motor innervation:

  • Extensor digitorum longus
  • Extensor hallucis longus
  • Tibialis anterior
  • Peroneus tertius

Sensory innervation:

  • The first interdigital space

The common peroneal nerve is more prone to injury as it lies superficial at the level of the lateral aspect of the neck of the fibula. Injury results in foot drop (which causes high-stepping gait), loss of eversion of the foot, and sensory loss on the dorsum of the foot.

Related Pearl: Sciatic nerve divisions and supply

semitendinous, semimembranous, long head biceps femoris, gastrocnemius popliteus, plantaris, soleus, tibialis posterior, flexor digitorum longus, flexor hallucis longus, abductor hallucis, flexor digit­orum brevis, flexor hallucis brevis, addcutor hallucis, foot interossei, abductor digiti minimi.

none
Peroneal division
Motor:
short head of biceps femoris, foot interossei, Tibialis anterior, Extensor Hallucis longus, Extensor digitorum longus and Peroneus tertius, Peroneus Longus, Peroneus Brevis.

questions.text:
Which of the following cells are present in the molecular layer of the cerebellum?

1. Stellate cells
2. Basket cells
3. Purkinje cells
4. Granular cells
questions.solution:
The molecular layer of the cerebellum contains stellate and basket cells.

The molecular layer is the outermost layer that contains stellate cells and basket cells, and dendrites of Purkinje cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. This layer contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers and appears pale on H&E staining.

Related Pearl: Layers of the cerebellar cortex

The cerebellar cortex is divided into 3 layers. They are:

  • Molecular layer - It is the outermost layer. It contains stellate cells and basket cells. They receive excitatory input from the parallel fibers and form inhibitory synapses on the Purkinje cells. It contains many myelinated and unmyelinated nerve fibers giving it a pale appearance in H and E staining.
  • Purkinje layer - It is the middle layer. It contain flask-shaped cell bodies of Purkinje cells. Their dendrites pass into the molecular layer. The axons of the Purkinje cells passes through the granular layer into the white matter and synapses with the cerebellar nuclei.
  • Granular layer - It is the innermost layer. It contains the cell bodies of the granule cells as well as Golgi cells. It receives excitatory input from the mossy fibers. They end on the dendrites of the granule cells and these complexes are called glomeruli. The axon from the granule cells travels to the molecular layer and bifurcates in a T-shape. These branches form the T and are called parallel fibers. These parallel fibers form excitatory synapses with the Purkinje cells. The granule cells form the only excitatory neurons in the cerebellar cortex. Golgi cells receive input from parallel fibers and mossy fibers. They send inhibitory output to the granule cells.

Neurotransmitters released:

  • Stellate, basket, Golgi and Purkinje cells- GABA
  • Granule cells - Glutamate

The only output from the cerebellar cortex is inhibitory from the Purkinje cells to the deep cerebellar nuclei.

questions.text: Bleeding as shown in the image is due to which of the following vessels?
questions.solution:
The image showing a bleed over the arachnoid layer but under the dura is suggestive of a subdural hemorrhage. Most commonly, it results from the shearing of cortical bridging veins.  

Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) is a collection of blood between the dura and the arachnoid layers of the meninges. The causes of SDH include

  • trauma
  • anticoagulants, antiplatelets
  • alcohol abuse
  • battered baby syndrome. 

Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice.

Other options:

Middle meningeal artery rupture would result in an extradural hemorrhage.

Lenticulostriate artery would lead to an intraparenchymal hemorrhage.

Vertebral artery dissection leads to subarachnoid hemorrhage or sometimes intraparenchymal hemorrhage.

 

The given image shows types of brain hemorrhage:

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about the internal capsule?
  1. Charcot's artery supplies the posterior limb.
  2. Retrolenticular part of the internal capsule contains optic radiation.
  3. Anterior limb of the capsule contains corticospinal tract fibers of the upper limb and face.
  4. Internal capsule has projection fibers.
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2, and 4 are true about the internal capsule.

The charcot’s artery of hemorrhage is a larger lenticulostriate or lateral striate artery. Lateral striate arteries supply the anterior limb, genu and the posterior limb of the internal capsule. These arteries are also commonly involved in ischemic and hemorrhagic strokes.

The retrolentiform part of the internal capsule carries fibers mainly from optic radiation. A lesion here produces homonymous hemianopia, superior quadrantanopia, or inferior quadrantanopia.

The anterior limb of the internal capsule carries fronto-pontine fibers. A lesion here produces confusion, impaired attention, agitation, and dysarthria.

The posterior limb of the internal capsule carries cortico-spinal motor fibers in the anterior part and the lesion here produces contralateral hemiparesis. The posterior part of the posterior limb of the internal capsule carries sensory fibers and lesions here may produce contralateral hemi-sensory deficits.

The internal capsule predominantly contains projection fibers, not commissural fibers. Projection fibers are the fibers that project from higher to lower centers or vice versa in CNS.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a branch of posterior division of internal iliac artery ?
questions.solution:
The inferior gluteal artery is a branch of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery.

 

Branches of the anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery:

  1. Obturator artery
  2. Superior vesical artery
  3. Inferior vesical artery 
  4. Inferior gluteal artery
  5. Middle rectal artery
  6. Vaginal artery (in females)
  7. Uterine artery (in females)
  8. Internal pudendal artery

  • Iliolumbar artery
  • Lateral sacral arteries
  • Superior gluteal artery

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding the marked structure.

choices.text: It is the meeting point of frontal, parietal, temporal and sphenoid bones.
Blow to the lateral side of the skull injures the marked structure.
Accessory middle meningeal artery lies under this structure.
It corresponds to site of anterolateral fontanelle of fetal skull.

questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the pterion. The incorrect statement is statement 3, which is the accessory middle meningeal artery lies under this structure.

The pterion is an H-shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

  1. Frontal bone
  2. Squamous part of the temporal bone
  3. Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  4. Parietal bone

It is located approximately 4 cm above the midpoint of the zygomatic arch. 

 

The pterion overlies the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and the lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere. The bone in this area is thin, and any injury to this area may lead to rupture of the middle meningeal artery, leading to extradural hematoma.

The pterion also corresponds to the site of the anterolateral (sphenoidal) fontanelle of the neonatal skull, which closes in the third month after birth.

 

The accessory meningeal artery may be a branch of the middle meningeal artery or might arise directly from the maxillary artery. It reaches the cranium via the foramen ovale and distributes principally in the extracranial region. It is distributed over the medial and lateral pterygoids, tensor veli palatini, greater wing and pterygoid processes of the sphenoid bone, mandibular nerve, and the otic ganglion. So, it supplies the trigeminal ganglion, dura mater and bone. But in some people, it may be replaced by small separate arteries.

questions.text:
What are the derivatives of the marked cells?
  1. Odontoblasts
  2. Sympathetic chain
  3. Melanocytes
  4. Nephrogenic cord
  5. Bulbus cordis
  6. Conotruncal septum
questions.solution:
The cells shown in the image are neural crest cells (NCC) present adjacent to the neural tube (NT). NCCs contribute to many organs and tissues, and the neural crest is sometimes referred to as the fourth germ layer:

  • In the trunk region, they form: 
    • Melanocytes
    • Sensory ganglia
    • Sympathetic and enteric neurons
    • Schwann cells
    • Adrenal medulla cells
  • In the cranial region, they contribute to the: 
    • Craniofacial skeleton
    • Neurons for cranial ganglia
    • Satellite glial cells
    • Melanocytes
  • Some of the other neural crest derivatives are
    • C cells of the thyroid gland
    • Conotruncal septum in the heart
    • Odontoblasts
    • Smooth muscle cells to blood vessels to the face and forebrain.

The intermediate mesoderm is a longitudinal strip of intraembryonic mesoderm that connects the paraxial with the lateral plate mesoderm. The intermediate mesoderm develops into the genital ridge and nephrogenic cord.

The majority of the heart, including the right ventricle and outflow tract, is derived from the bulbus cordis, which is further derived from the pharyngeal mesoderm.

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Mesoderm

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles form the pelvic diaphragm?

A. Iliococcygeus
B. Pubococcygeus
C. Obturator internus
D. Deep transverse perinei
questions.solution:
Iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus are parts of the pelvic diaphragm, which is also known as the levator ani.

The levator ani muscle is a complex unit that consists of 3 muscle components:

  • Pubococcygeus
    • Pubovaginalis - elevates the urethra and hence contributes to urinary continence
    • Puboperinealis - draws the perineal body towards the pubic symphysis
    • Puboanalis - elevates the anus and keeps the urogenital hiatus narrowed
  • Puborectalis
  • Iliococcygeus

Levator ani muscles are the most important muscles in the pelvic floor and maintain a constant state of contraction. They provide a stable floor and support the weight of the abdominopelvic contents against intra-abdominal forces. Weakening of levator ani and pelvic fascia from stretching or tearing during childbirth, may decrease support for the vagina, bladder, uterus, or rectum or alter the position of the neck of the bladder and urethra.

Other options: 

The obturator internus forms the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa and is not a part of the levator ani.

The deep transverse perineal muscle is the content of the deep perineal space and contributes to the formation of the perineal body.

Related Pearl: DeLancey's levels of support of the genital organs

Level of support Structures forming the support Consequence of damage
Level 1

The cardinal-uterosacral ligament complex provides apical attachment of the uterus and vaginal vault to the bony sacrum

Uterine descent

Vault descent

Enterocele
Level 2

Lateral attachments provide support to the middle part of the vagina. The anterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to arcus tendinous fascia pelvis and the posterior vaginal wall is attached laterally to the facia overlying the levator ani muscle. 

Cystocele

Rectocele
Level 3

The urogenital diaphragm (Deep perineal muscles & Perineal membrane) and the perineal body provide support to the lower part of the vagina. 

Urethrocele

Gaping introitus

Deficient perineum

questions.text: Which of the following arteries passes in close proximity to the area marked by the arrow in the given image?

choices.text: Anterior division of middle cerebral artery
Anterior division of the middle meningeal artery
Posterior division of middle cerebral artery

questions.solution:
The area marked by an arrow in the given image is pterion and the artery that passes in close proximity to this area is the middle meningeal artery.

The pterion is an H shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

  • Frontal bone
  • Squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • Parietal bone.

It is an important structure as it overlies the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere. The bone in this area is thin and any injury to this area may lead to rupture of the middle meningeal artery leading to extradural hematoma.

questions.text: Fracture of the jugular canal can present as

choices.text: Loss of taste sensation in anterioir 2/3rd of tongue
Loss of taste sensation in posterior 1/3rd of tongue
Loss of general sensation in anterior 2/3rd of tongue
Loss of motor sensation in anterior 2/3rd of tongue

questions.solution:
Fracture of the jugular canal affects glossopharyngeal nerve and presents as loss of taste sensation in the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue. 

The lingual nerve which is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve gives general sensation, chorda tympani branch of facial nerve gives taste sensation for the anterior 2/3rd of tongue. Both taste and general sensation of the posterior 1/3rd is by the glossopharyngeal nerve. The muscles of the tongue, with the exception of palatoglossus, are supplied by the hypoglossal nerve. Palatoglossus is supplied via the pharyngeal plexus.

The other nerves passing through the jugular foramen are glossopharyngeal(cranial nerve IX), vagus(cranial nerve X), and accessory nerve(cranial nerve XI).

The following is an image of the base of skull showing jugular foramen:

questions.text: Injury of the lower brachial plexus leads to Klumpke's paralysis. What is the characteristic clinical finding seen in this lesion?
questions.solution:
The characteristic clinical finding in Klumpke's paralysis is a complete claw hand.

Klumpke's paralysis is caused by injury of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus-mainly T1 and partially C8, due to traction injury of the lower trunk that may be seen in undue abduction of the arm (outstretched arm grabbing an object during a fall from height) or birth injury (traction of the extended arm during delivery) 

This leads to paralysis of the intrinsic muscles of the hand (T1) that are responsible for flexion at metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP) and extension at proximal and distal interphalangeal joints(PIP and DIP). The unopposed action of extensor digitorum at MCP causes hyperextension. The unopposed action of flexor digitorum superficialis and profundus at PIP and DIP causes flexion. Thus giving rise to the characteristic claw hand.

Other changes include anesthesia and analgesia along the ulnar border of the forearm, vasomotor changes, absence of sweating, and trophic changes in long-standing cases. If the C8 is also damaged, the extent of anesthesia will be greater and will involve the medial side of the forearm, hand, and medial two fingers.

Horner's syndrome (option D) may occur in one-third of the cases due to injury of sympathetic fibers to the head and neck that leave the spinal cord through nerve T1.

The following image shows a complete claw hand in Klumpke's paralysis:

 

 

Other options:

Option A: Policeman tip deformity, also known as waiter's tip hand or porter's tip hand, is a finding of Erb's palsy due to injury of the upper trunk of the brachial plexus involving C5 and C6. The hand is adducted, medially rotated, and hangs by the side with the elbow extended and pronated. 

The following image shows policeman tip deformity in Erb's palsy:

 

Option B: Wrist drop is a feature of radial nerve injury in the axilla, radial groove, anterolateral side of the lower arm, or injury of the deep branch in the cubital fossa.

Option D: Horner's syndrome is caused due to the disruption of sympathetic supply to the face. It causes ptosis, miosis, anhydrosis, enophthalmos, and loss of ciliospinal reflex of the affected eye. It may occur in some cases of Klumpke's paralysis and is not a characteristic finding.

The following image shows the ocular manifestation of Horner syndrome:

Related Pearl: Brachial Plexus

Brachial Plexus

  • C5 to T1
  • Roots (from spinal cord) > Trunks (in the neck)> Divisions (passing behind clavicle) > Cords and Branches (in the axilla).
  • Covered by prevertebral fascia extension called "axillary sheath"

Trunks:

  • Upper trunk: C5 and C6
  • Middle trunk: C7.
  • Lower trunk: C8 and T1

Divisions:

  • Anterior divisions - Forms lateral and medial cords supplying mainly flexors 
  • Posterior divisions - Forms posterior cord which suppy mainly extensors 

Cords:

  • Lateral cord: Formed by anterior divisions of the upper and middle trunks.
  • Posterior cord: Formed by all 3 posterior divisions 
  • Medial cord: Formed by anterior division of the lower trunk.

questions.text: Identify the liver segment marked in the image below:
questions.solution:
The liver segment highlighted in green in this CT section is segment V. The section of the CT given is taken below the portal vein as the cross-section of the portal vein before its bifurcation can be viewed.

A horizontal plane known as the portal plane divides the liver where the portal vein bifurcates and becomes horizontal. This divides each section of the liver into superior and inferior segments: 

  • Left lateral section: segment II above and segment III below the portal plane
  • Left medial section: segment IVa above and segment IVb below the portal plane
  • Right anterior (or medial) section: segment VIII above and segment V below the portal plane
  • Right posterior (or lateral) section: segment VII above and segment VI below the portal plane

 Shown below is a section from below the portal plane.

Couinaud classification is the commonly used classification of the liver. It divides the liver is divided into eight segments. It is based on the distribution of portal venous branches in the liver parenchyma. Each segment has its own vascular supply, biliary drainage, and lymphatic drainage.

The Couinaud's liver segments are as follows:

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the lung is affected when there is aspiration in supine position?

choices.text: Upper part of right inferior lobe

questions.solution:
The upper part of the right inferior lobe is prone to aspiration in the supine position. It is commonly seen in alcoholics.

The posterior segment of the right superior lobe and the superior segment of the inferior lobes are the most commonly involved lung sites when aspiration occurs in a recumbent patient.

The location of aspiration depends on the position of the patient since it is gravity-dependent. Aspiration while standing leads to infiltration of bilateral inferior lobes because of larger and more vertical corresponding bronchi, the middle lobes and the lingula.

Aspiration of contents into foreign substances into the bronchial tree, usually oral or gastric contents, produces aspiration pneumonia. Chemical (gastric acid) injury or bacterial infection complicates the condition.

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve that arises from the marked part.
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the abducens nerve that arises from the pontomedullary junction.

In the groove between the medulla and pons, abducens, facial, and vestibulocochlear nerves emerge arranged medially to laterally.

The abducens nerve is the 6th cranial nerve that arises from the brainstem at the pontomedullary junction, passes through Dorello's canal, and enters the cavernous sinus where it lies lateral to the internal carotid artery. It then enters the orbit through the common tendinous ring in the superior orbital fissure to supply the lateral rectus.

  • VI, VII, and VIII cranial nerves:  Pontomedullary junction
  • IX, X, and XI cranial nerves(nucleus ambiguus): Posterolateral sulcus   
  • XII cranial nerve: Anterolateral sulcus (between pyramid and olive)

questions.text:
Which of the following are a part of the limbic system?

1. Amygdala
2. Hippocampus
3. Thalamus
questions.solution:
The amygdala, hippocampus, and thalamus are all a part of the limbic system.

The limbic system refers to the interconnected neuronal circuit in the basal part of the brain that controls emotional behavior and other vegetative functions such as body temperature, the osmolality of the body fluids, and the drives to eat and drink and to control body weight.

The limbic system includes the following:

  • Subcallosal gyrus
  • Cingulate gyrus
  • Parahippocampal gyrus
  • Hippocampal formation
  • Amygdaloid nucleus
  • Mammillary bodies
  • Anterior thalamic nucleus
  • Hypothalamus

The connecting pathways for this system comprise the alveus, the fimbria, the fornix, the mammillothalamic tract, and the stria terminalis.

Related Pearl: Components of limbic system

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presented with a positive Trendelenburg test on the right side. Identify the nerve injured.
questions.solution:
Positive Trendelenburg test on the right side indicates a right superior gluteal nerve injury.
When the patient stands on his right foot, there is drooping of the left pelvis, this is a Positive Trendelenburg test on the right side.

The gluteus medius and minimus are powerful abductors of the hip supplied by the superior gluteal nerve.

Normally, when the leg is lifted off the ground, the gluteus medius and minimus on the opposite (unsupported) side exert traction on the hip bone. This results in a slight raising of the pelvis on the unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk upright position.

If the gluteus medius and minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis drops on the contralateral side. This is known as a positive Trendelenburg sign. It is positive in the paralysis of the hip abductors, and in developmental dysplasia of the hip. A characteristic lurching gait is seen.

The image below shows the Trendelenburg test.
